questions.text: Which of the following is the pattern of inheritance with the pedigree chart provided in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial inheritance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by the transmission of a trait from an affected mother to all of her offspring, while affected males do not pass the trait to their children. This unique pattern is due to the inheritance of mitochondrial DNA, which is maternally inherited.
  • ➤ Example of Maternal/ mitochondrial inheritance diseases: Leber's Optic Neuropathy , MELAS Syndrome (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like manifestation).
  • ➤ Leber's Optic Neuropathy

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Falciform ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Falciform Ligament is derived from the ventral mesogastrium. This sickle-shaped ligament runs from the anterior abdominal wall to the liver, effectively connecting the liver to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall. The ligamentum teres (remnant of the umbilical vein) runs within the free edge of this ligament.
  • ➤ Falciform Ligament

questions.text: What will be the duration of below-knee POP cast applied for the following injury?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6-8 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fractures of the metatarsals, including those at the base of the fifth metatarsal, are typically treated with a below-knee plaster cast for a duration of 6-8 weeks to ensure proper healing.
  • ➤ 6-8 weeks

questions.text: How much is the distance between the victim and the firearm from the gunshot entry based on the wound given below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tattooing (stippling) around a gunshot wound indicates a close contact or intermediate range. The absence of singeing or blackening suggests the firearm was not in direct contact but was fired from a short distance, such as close contact.

questions.text: A Mediterranean person didn’t receive primaquine. Which pathway is affected by G-6-PD enzyme deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HMP pathway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G6PD is the first and rate limiting enzyme of HMP pathway which is the major source of NADPH that is required for reduced glutathione generation and help reduce oxidative stress by neutralizing free radicals.
  • ➤ Primaquine is an antimalarial drug and causes oxidative stress. In patients with Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase ( G6PD) deficiency, primaquine can cause hemolysis so it is avoided.
  • ➤ Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 182

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nicotinic acid when given orally or parenterally produces a transient vasodilatation of the cutaneous vessels and histamine release. The reaction is accompanied by itching, burning and tingling . Intake of nicotinic acid in excess of 50 mg/day may lead to liver damage (Raised AST and ALT levels, Fulminant hepatitis)
  • ➤ histamine release.
  • ➤ itching, burning
  • ➤ and tingling
  • ➤ Niacin causes a reversible toxic cystoid maculopathy that occurs in approximately 0.67% of patients taking high doses of the drug.
  • ➤ reversible toxic cystoid maculopathy
  • ➤ Other symptoms –
  • ➤ Other symptoms –
  • ➤ Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Glucose intolerance (therefore weekly glucose monitoring done if given in diabetics) Hyperuricemia
  • ➤ Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • ➤ Glucose intolerance (therefore weekly glucose monitoring done if given in diabetics)
  • ➤ Glucose intolerance
  • ➤ Hyperuricemia

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chiari malformation is diagnosed by the inferior displacement of the cerebellar tonsils below the foramen magnum, typically more than 5 mm, seen on imaging.

questions.text: A PLHIV with low CD4 count admitted with pneumonia. GMS stain of BAL shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of pneumonia in HIV patients with low CD4 counts and is identified by its characteristic crushed ping-pong ball appearance in GMS-stained samples.

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lower segment cesarean section

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a case of deep transverse arrest with features of CPD, a lower segment cesarean section is the appropriate management to prevent complications and ensure safe delivery.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2D. This is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic malnutrition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Height for age < -2SD is indicative of chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, which results from prolonged inadequate nutrition, particularly during the critical early years of a child's life.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 18%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients. For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA. This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.
  • ➤ Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • ➤ For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • ➤ This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

questions.text: In a cohort study done in a community, out of those 100 vaccinated for malaria, only 6 developed the disease. At the same time, out of those 100 non-vaccinated, a total of 12 developed the disease. Find the relative risk in the study: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a cohort study, the relative risk is calculated by comparing the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group to the incidence in the non-exposed group.
  • ➤ A relative risk less than 1 indicates a protective effect of the exposure, as seen in this example where vaccination reduced the risk of malaria.

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

options.label: B
options.text: E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

options.label: C
options.text: E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

options.label: D
options.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.correct_answer: A. E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.
  • • Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles
  • • Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.
  • • Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase:
  • • Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • • Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase:
  • • Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.
  • • Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref-Harper 31 st e/pg. 162
  • ➤ Ref-Harper 31 st e/pg. 162

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.
  • ➤ Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.
  • ➤ Oxidase test
  • ➤ Oxidase positive organisms:
  • ➤ Oxidase positive organisms:
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Pseudomonas ﻿﻿Vibrio ﻿﻿Helicobacter ﻿﻿Campylobacter ﻿﻿Pasteurella ﻿﻿Legionella ﻿﻿Neisseria ﻿﻿Brucella ﻿﻿Moraxella ﻿Burkholderia
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Pseudomonas

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in a female with dysuria and vesicles for which she underwent an examination that revealed the presence of cells as shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes simplex virus infection is identified by multinucleated giant cells, nuclear molding, and margination on Tzanck smear, distinguishing it from other genital infections.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tubercular osteomyelitis is not true? (NEET PG 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: It is a type of secondary osteomyelitis

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Periosteal reaction is characteristic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unlike pyogenic osteomyelitis, tubercular osteomyelitis typically presents with well-defined bone destruction, minimal periosteal reaction, less prominent sequestrum formation, and chronic granulomatous inflammation rather than acute suppurative changes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pompholyx is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.correct_answer: B. Most common site is soles
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Most common site is soles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pompholyx is characterized by intensely pruritic deep-seated vesicles with sago grain-like appearance occurring primarily on fingers and palms , less commonly on soles, and typically presents with symmetric distribution.
  • ➤ Pompholyx is characterized by intensely pruritic deep-seated vesicles with sago grain-like appearance occurring primarily on fingers and palms , less commonly on soles, and typically presents with symmetric distribution.
  • ➤ pruritic deep-seated vesicles
  • ➤ sago grain-like
  • ➤ fingers and palms
  • ➤ symmetric distribution.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought with bow legs and on x-ray of wrist, following were the findings. The child also had low serum calcium and low serum phosphate values. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image of the child’s hands and wrists shows cupping and splaying of the radius and the ulna. The patient presents with bow legs, and decreased levels of serum calcium and phosphate. These are common findings of rickets caused by defective bone mineralization or nutritional deficiency of vitamin D in children.
  • ➤ The given image of the child’s hands and wrists shows cupping and splaying of the radius and the ulna.
  • ➤ The patient presents with bow legs, and decreased levels of serum calcium and phosphate.
  • ➤ These are common findings of rickets caused by defective bone mineralization or nutritional deficiency of vitamin D in children.

questions.text: Which one of the following leads to shift toward red curve in the given graph? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) shows the relationship between PO2 and hemoglobin saturation . The red curve in the image represents a right shift. Acidosis causes a right shift of the curve, known as the Bohr effect. When blood pH decreases (acidosis), the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen decreases, causing more oxygen to be released to the tissues. This is physiologically beneficial as tissues in acidotic conditions often need more oxygen.
  • • PO2 and hemoglobin saturation
  • • Bohr effect.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Less 2,3 BPG: Incorrect Less 2,3-BPG causes a left shift of the curve, not right
  • • Option B. Less 2,3 BPG: Incorrect
  • • When 2,3-BPG levels decrease, hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen increases This means oxygen binds more tightly to hemoglobin and less is released to tissues
  • • When 2,3-BPG levels decrease, hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen increases
  • • This means oxygen binds more tightly to hemoglobin and less is released to tissues
  • • Option C. Hypocarbia: Incorrect Hypocarbia means decreased CO2 levels
  • • Option C. Hypocarbia: Incorrect
  • • This leads to alkalosis which causes a left shift Results in increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen
  • • This leads to alkalosis which causes a left shift
  • • Results in increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen
  • • Option D. Hypothermia: Incorrect Lower temperature causes a left shift of the curve
  • • Option D. Hypothermia: Incorrect
  • • Increases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen Reduces oxygen delivery to tissues
  • • Increases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen
  • • Reduces oxygen delivery to tissues

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acidosis causes a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (Bohr effect), while alkalosis, hypothermia, and decreased 2,3-BPG cause left shifts.

questions.text: Identify the following sign: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tear drop sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows the tear drop sign (also called hanging drop sign) because:
  • • Shows herniation of orbital contents into maxillary sinus Appears as a tear-shaped shadow on imaging Characteristic finding in orbital floor fractures (blow-out fractures) Occurs due to disruption of orbital floor allowing downward displacement of orbital contents Important radiological sign in trauma cases

  • • Appears as a tear-shaped shadow on imaging
  • • Characteristic finding in orbital floor fractures (blow-out fractures)
  • • Occurs due to disruption of orbital floor allowing downward displacement of orbital contents
  • • Important radiological sign in trauma cases
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Steeple sign
  • • Option B. Steeple sign
  • • Seen in croup Shows subglottic narrowing on AP view Appears as narrowing of upper airway Different radiological appearance
  • • Seen in croup
  • • Shows subglottic narrowing on AP view
  • • Appears as narrowing of upper airway
  • • Different radiological appearance
  • • Option C. Thumb sign
  • • Option C. Thumb sign
  • • Seen in acute epiglottitis Shows swollen epiglottis on lateral neck X-ray Appears as thumb-like shadow Different anatomical location
  • • Seen in acute epiglottitis
  • • Shows swollen epiglottis on lateral neck X-ray
  • • Appears as thumb-like shadow
  • • Different anatomical location
  • • Option D. Sail sign
  • • Option D. Sail sign
  • • Not a commonly used radiological sign in ENT Different appearance and location Not related to orbital or sinus pathology
  • • Not a commonly used radiological sign in ENT
  • • Different appearance and location
  • • Not related to orbital or sinus pathology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the tear drop sign (hanging drop sign) as characteristic radiological finding in orbital floor fractures showing herniation of orbital contents into maxillary sinus

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with palpitations and giddiness. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. ECG shows absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cardioversion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a case of atrial fibrillation (AF) with hemodynamic instability . The diagnosis is supported by:
  • • atrial fibrillation (AF) with hemodynamic instability
  • • ECG findings of absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval – Classic for AF Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg) – Indicates hemodynamic compromise Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness – Suggest compromised cardiac output
  • • ECG findings of absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval – Classic for AF
  • • ECG findings
  • • irregularly irregular RR interval
  • • AF
  • • Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg) – Indicates hemodynamic compromise
  • • Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg)
  • • hemodynamic compromise
  • • Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness – Suggest compromised cardiac output
  • • Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness
  • • In any tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability ( systolic BP < 90 mmHg ), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice , regardless of the specific arrhythmia. This is because unstable blood pressure indicates that the patient is in shock and requires immediate rhythm restoration.
  • • tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability
  • • systolic BP < 90 mmHg
  • • immediate synchronized cardioversion
  • • treatment of choice
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Adenosine: Incorrect
  • • Option A. Adenosine:
  • • Used primarily for PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia) Not effective in atrial fibrillation (in fact C/I !!)
  • • Used primarily for PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia)
  • • Not effective in atrial fibrillation (in fact C/I !!)
  • • Option B. Verapamil: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Verapamil:
  • • Useful in rate control for stable AF Contraindicated in hypotensive patients as it can worsen hypotension Reserved for hemodynamically stable patients
  • • Useful in rate control for stable AF
  • • Contraindicated in hypotensive patients as it can worsen hypotension
  • • Contraindicated in hypotensive patients
  • • Reserved for hemodynamically stable patients
  • • Option C. Amiodarone: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Amiodarone:
  • • Effective for AF, but has a delayed onset of action Not appropriate when immediate rhythm restoration is needed due to instability Better suited for maintenance therapy or rhythm control in stable patients
  • • Effective for AF, but has a delayed onset of action
  • • Not appropriate when immediate rhythm restoration is needed due to instability
  • • Better suited for maintenance therapy or rhythm control in stable patients

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability ( systolic BP < 90 mmHg ), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia type.
  • ➤ tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability
  • ➤ systolic BP < 90 mmHg
  • ➤ immediate synchronized cardioversion

questions.text: Which family member is responsible for transmission of the disease in mitochondrial inheritance? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mother

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial inheritance follows a maternal transmission pattern in which only mothers can pass mitochondrial DNA mutations to their children. This occurs because all mitochondria in humans are inherited from the mother's egg cell, while paternal mitochondria are eliminated during fertilization.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about spasmodic dysphonia is not true? (NEET PG 2016)

options.label: A
options.text: It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles.

options.label: B
options.text: Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin.

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required.

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

questions.correct_answer: D. Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This statement is incorrect because patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia actually present with a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice, not a strained and strangled voice. The strained or strangled voice quality with phonation interruptions and voice breaks is characteristic of Adductor Dysphonia, where the adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to adduct excessively.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles. This is true. Spasmodic dysphonia involves abnormal muscular contractions (spasms) of the laryngeal muscles during speech. The condition can involve either adductor or abductor muscles, causing different voice patterns.
  • • Option A. It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles.
  • • Option B. Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin. This is true. Botulinum toxin injections are the standard treatment for both adductor and abductor spasmodic dysphonia. In adductor type, injections target the thyroarytenoid muscle, while in abductor type, the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are injected.
  • • Option B. Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin.
  • • Option C. Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required. This is true. The benefit of botulinum toxin injections typically lasts only up to 16 weeks, after which repeat injections are needed. This makes it a recurring treatment rather than a one-time solution.
  • • Option C. Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adductor and Abductor spasmodic dysphonias present with distinctly different voice qualities - strained/strangled in adductor type versus breathy in abductor type - though both are treated with botulinum toxin injections that require periodic repetition due to their temporary effect.
